p.seg: Heaven possesses light;
it is not distressed by the darkness in which men live.
Earth possesses riches;
it is not distressed by the poverty in which men live.
The sage possesses power,
but he is not distressed by the peril in which men live.
Though Heaven is not distressed by the darkness in which men live,
yet by opening doors and parting windows, men may unfailingly draw from it their own light.
It follows then that Heaven hs no tasks to attend to.
3. Though Earth is not distressed by the poverty inwhich men live,
yet, by felling trees and cutting grass, men may unfailingly draw from it their own wealth.
It follows then that Earth has no tasks to attend do.
4. Though the sage is not distressed by the peril in whihc men live,
yet the people may, by being submissive to the sovereign and concordant in their subject status,
unfailingly draw from him their own security. It follows then that the sage has no tasks to attend to.
5. Thus when it is said that the Sage in his position as sovereign
is able not to do men harm
but is unable to free men from harm of their own making,
it implies that the people rid themselves of the things which cause them harm.
is due to his having been given it
not to his having taken it;
the proper relationship of the people to the Sage
6. That the sage possesses the world
is that they supply his necessities.
not that they cause the Sage to supply their necessities.
It follows then that the sage has no task to attend to.
7. Though Mao Ch'iang and Xi Shih
were the most beautiful women in the world,
if one were to dress them in [bear]-skin and demon-masks
everyone who saw them would run away;
but if one were to have them change into fine black linen
everyone who walked by them would stop in his tracks.
8. So it can be seen
that fine black linen is an aid to beauty.
If the comely dispense with it,
their beauty will be unpleasing.
9. Carriers can make their way beyond the farthest valley
only because of the ointment [they apply].
and walk through the wilderness for thousands of miles,
If carriers dispense with ointment,
their feet will be ruined.
10. Thus when it is said that
The Rearing Serpent sports in the mists,
The Flying Dragon rides on the clouds,
But when the clouds are gone and the mists have cleared, they are no different from earthworms.
the point is that they have lost the vehicles on which they rode.
11. Thus when men of excellence are oppressed by a worthless man
it means that their authority is not as weighty as his;
when worthless men are subjected to a man of excellence,
it means that his position is more exalted than theirs.
As a simple yeoman, Yao
could not command his neighbors,
but once he had faced South as King,
then, "what he ordered was done and what he forbade ceased to be done."
13. From this it can be seen
that excellence is not enough to bring worthlessness into subjection,
but that circumstances and position are enough to bend excellence under oppression.

14. Thus, when a decisive role is played by a man of no repute, 【14: “Nobody” = “nameless person”. “Name” indicates fame or membership in an eminent family. In a well-ordered state, reputation and family connections will not get you a government job. See also section F below, and
it is because his authority has weight;
when a bolt flies high from a weak crossbow,
is it because it is carried on the wind;
when the orders of a person of no worth are carried out,
it is because he received aid from many.
15. Thus, one who carries heavy burdens and crosses high mountains
is not careless about the use of ointment;
one who loves little children
is not careless about the choice of a nurse;
one who travels on dangerous roads and journeys to distant places
is not careless aobut the choice of a driver.
These are illustrations of the principle that "aid obtained means success;
aid rejected means ruin.
16. That the ower of the Three Kings and the Five Protectors
was of the same order as that of Heaven and Earth,
that it had access to the world of demons and gods,
and embraced all living things,
was due to the fact that they obtained aid from all.
17. In antiquity, the artisans did not perform more than one task
and the well-born did not hold more than one office..
Since the artisans did not perform more than one task, there tasks were lessened;
and since their tasks were lessened, it was easy to master them.
Since the well-born did not hold more than one office,their duties were few;
and since their duties were few, it was easy to discharge them.
Therefore it was possible for the positions of the well-born to be held a lifetime,
and for the tasks of the artisans to conform to constant standards.
18. "The sons of artisans have ability without having to learn."
This does not mean that they are born with their skills;
it refers to the fact that they perform tasks which conform to constant standards.
19. In these present times, the state is not guided by the constant Way
and his officials are not regulated by constant laws.
This is why the state is daily enmeshed in greater error.
the officials are unqualified [to practise them].
When the officials are unqualified, the principles of the Way languish.
Even where the doctrines [of the Way] are perfectly formulated,
When the principles of the Way languish, the excellent and the wise are admired.

When the excellent and the wise are admired, the most vital functions in the administration of the State are left to the discretion of a single man. 【Presumably because there is no way to select administrative personal with these admired qualifications other than by the private judgment of the ruler.】
21. In antiquity, the intent of [the injunction], "Establish the Son of Heaven and honor him,"
that unless there was a single object of honor, without peer in the world,
was not to bring benefit to a single man.
It meant rather
the principles [of the Way] would have no point of access [to the world].
The access to the principles [of the Way] is for the sake of the whole world.
22. Thus, it is the case that the Son of Heaven is established for the sake of the whole world,
not that the whole world is established for the sake of the Son of Heaven;
that the ruler of a state is established for the sake of the state,
not that the state is established for the sake of the ruler;
and that the incumbent of an office is established for the sake of the office,
not that the office is established for the sake of the incumbent.
Even though the laws are not good,
they still are preferable to no laws at all.
24. The reason people throw buckles and apportion property,
and throw whips to apportion horses,
is not because buckles and whips give equal portions.
They keep those who receive get the better portion from knowing whom they should be grateful to,
and keep those who receive the worse portion from knowing whom they should be resentful of.
These are means by which to prevent resentment and expectation from arising.
25. The discerning ruler never initiates tasks or apportions duties by any criterion other than aptitude;
he never determines offenses or apportions property on any principle other than the laws;
he never exercises his personal power or asserts his central control through any channel other than the formal modes of conduct.
26. Thus, desire does not disturb the seasonal cycle,
nor does affection violate the law;
honors do not exceed the statutory limits,
nor do emoluments exceed the position held;
the well-born do not hold more than one office,
nor do the artisans perform more than one task.
27. Let tasks be assigned according to abilities;
let benefits be received according to the task performed.
When this is the case
there will be no excessive rewards from the sovereign
and there will be no excessive riches among the subjects.
It is the Way of Heaven that the results of accommodation are great
and that the results of alteration are small.
By "accommodation"
is meant accommodation to human reality.
There is no man who does not act in self-interest.
30. For this reason, when the Former Kings met those who would not accept emolument they did not make them their servants;
and they did not allow those whose emolument was not large to share their lot in times of difficulty.
31. In situations where men would be denied the means to act in their own self-interest,
the sovereign does not offer employment.
32. Thus, if one makes use of men's self-interest
and not of what men do to serve one's own interest,
then there is no man that one cannot use.
This is meant by 'accommodation".
33. The people live in diverse conditions and circumstances, but each of them has his own abilities,
Thweir abilities are not the sme.
This is an essential characteristic of the people.
34. The "Great Ruler"
is the Most Sovereign,
the one who keeps in his care all who are subjects.
The abilities of subjects are not the same
but all are of use to the Sovereign.
35. For this reason the Great Ruler looks on the abilities of the people as his given resources
and accommodates himself to them, keeping all of them in his protection and care.
He does not reject some and accept others. 【omit the 能 after 無。based on the NCL MS. See Bibliograpy for abbreviation.】
36. This being so, he does not set up a unique formula
for seeking men,
and as a consequence he always finds sufficient for his needs.
It is because the Great Ruler does not select his subjects,
that they are sufficient
Since he does not select his subjects,
it is easy to become a subject.
When it is easy to become a subject, the status of subject excludes no one.
The consequence of excluding no one is that one's subjects will be the most numerous.
For one's subjects to be the most numerous is what is meant by being "the Most Sovereign."
38.The Way of Rulers and Servants
is such that while the servants perform the tasks the ruler has no tasks to perform;
that while the ruler enjoys ease and pleasure, the servants endure responsibility and arduous exertions;
and that while the servants exhaust their knowledge and strength to perform their tasks well,
the ruler contributes nothing -
with the consequence that all tasks are performed in good order.
This is what the Correct Way of Good Order is like.
he simply awaits the consummation,
39. When a ruler of men assumes responsibilities himself and strives to do his best in order to put the interests of his subjects before his own,
it is a case of "carrying burdens and undertaking labors in the place of subjects
and the servants, in complete reversal of their proper roles, will then enjoy a life of ease.
40. Thus it is said,
"If one who rules men is fond of doing his best in order to put the interests of his subjects before his own
then the subjects will not dare to compete with their ruler by doing their best to put their ruler's interests before their own."
Whhen [those below]... all treat what they know as the private possession under which to hide themselves,
and when, in cases of transgression, the servants completely reverse their proper relationship with their ruler by putting the blame on him,
it is the Way of opposition and chaos.
The intelligence of the ruler is not necessarily of a higher order of excellence than that of all others.
With less than the highest excellence, should he wish, by being a good ruler, to take care of all his subjects,
he would fail to supply them with sufficient for their needs.
43.Even supposing the intelligence of the ruler to be of the highest excellence,
if he were, by his single-handed efforts as ruler, to supply all his subjects with sufficient for their needs, it would mean enduring arduous exertions;
arduous exertions would lead to fatigue;
fatigue would led to exhaustion;
and exhaustion would bring him back to the Way of Insufficiency.
44. Therefore, if a ruler of men assumes responsibilities himself and performs tasks personally,
the servants will not apply themselves to the performace of tasks.
This would be for ruler and servants to exchange positions
and could be characterised as "Inversion and opposition."
From Inversion and opposition there follows chaos.
45. If a ruler of men gives responsibilities to his servants and does not become personally involved himself,
the servants will apply themselves to the performance of tasks.
This is the proper subordination between ruler and servants,
and is what makes the difference between order and chaos.
It is essential that it be given the closest scrutiny.
46. Servants, who in times of chaos,
bring about the downfall of their stat
are not to be accounted for by the mere fact that they include no loyal servants in their number;
servants who, in well ordered states,
bring renown to their ruler
are not to be accounted for by the mere fact that they are capable of the utmost loyalty.
47. Even amongst men who live in well-ordered states
loyalty is not given exclusively to the ruler;
even amongst men who live in times of chaos,
lip-service is not practised universally by the servants.
This being so, times of order and of chaos
are equally provided with loyal and with lip-serving men.
48. Servants with the desire to be loyal have existed in all age,
and yet rulers have not succeeded in enjoying their sovereign status in tranquillity.
Even when they have encountered loyalty to the point of self-destruction, as in [Prince] Pi-kan or in [Wu] Tzu-hsü,
masters and rulers have lived in the darkness and blackness [of ignorance] and have subsequently gone to their deaths,
drowned in evil and covered in ignominy.
49. This shows
that loyalty is not enough to redeem an age of chaos,
but that it is just what is needed to aggravate its ills.
How may we know that this is true?
The father ad a good son,
Shun banished Ku-sou;
Hsieh had loyal servants
but transgression filled the world.
50. So it follows that Filial sons do not arise in the families of compassionate fathers;
And loyal servants do not arise among the subjects of sage rulers.
51. Thus in the delopment of his servants the discerning master
does not allow their loyalty to exceed the requiorements of their duties,
nor their duties to exceed the specifications of their office.
In this way his own "excesses" are purged away
and his subjects do not dare to be arrogant and conceited on account of the quality of their performance.
52. When officials charged with duties
devote themselves one and all to their proper jurisdictions and none dares to abuse the privileges or to slight the responsibilities of his tasks;
when they show their dedication to their calling by being upright in their offices,
and serve their sovereign in harmony and submissiveness;
the Perfect Order has been achieved.
53. The ruler who brings about the downfall of the state
is not the product of one man's faults;
the ruler who brings order to the state
is not the product of one man's efforts.
54. If one would bring order out of disorder, the crucial point is that agent of high excellence should bear responsibility for the duties of government;
the crucial point is not loyalty.
57. Thus A world full of wisdom
is a blessing to the ruler;
A world full of loyalty
is a bane to the state.
Thus, although Yao would not have been able to preserve himself t
he conditions which caused Chieh to fall,
yet Yao is credited with supreme goodness,
while Chieh has a reputation for all-pervading evil.
It follows then that it is a question of whether one succeeds or fails in finding the right men [to match one].
56. Thus the timber in the Great Hall of State is,
after all, not cut from the graches of one tree;
a coat of white fox-fur
is, after all, not made from the pelt of one fox;
and the dispensation of order or disorder, of security or peril, of preservation or downfall, of honor or disgrace,
is not achieved through the efforts of one man.
The raising up of a Son of Heaven is to prevent the Grat Lords from assuming his role;
the raaising up the Great Lords is to prevent the nobles from assuming their role;
the raising up of a principal wife is to prevent the minor wives from assuming her role;
the raising up of a legitimate heir is to prevent the sons ofconcubines from assuming this role.
Where there is confusion of roles there will be turmoil,
where there is duality, there will be contention;
Where there is diversity, there will be injury.
The cause of harm lies in the sharing [of power],
not in its uniqueness.
58. Thus, when two servants share the highest post, the state will certainly fall into chaos.
In cases where two servants share the highest post and the state does not fall into chaos,
it is because the ruler is still present.
As long as such a state depends on the ruler,
but when it loses the ruler, it will certainly fall into chaos.
59. When two sons share the highest place, the family will certainly fall into chaos.
In cases where two sons share the highest place and the family does not fall into chaos,
it is because the parents are still present.
As long as such a family depends on the parents, it will not fall into chaos;
but when it loses the parents, it will certainly fall into chaos.
60. There is no state in which a servant assumes the role of his ruler, which is not in peril;
there is no family in which the son of a concubine assumes the role of the head of the family, which is not in peril.
61. When one who rules men
casts aside the laws and governs on his own initiative,
then punishments and rewards, seizures and and grants will be measured out according to the discretion of the ruler.
When that is so, then those who are rewarded, even if they receive what they deserve,
will always expect a greater reward,
and those who are penalised, even if they receive what they deserve,
will always expect a lighter penalty.
62. For the ruler to cast aside the laws and judge degrees of merit and demerit according to his own discretion
is to give "different reawards for the same accomplishments
and different penalties for the same offenses;"
it is the source from which resentment arrises.
63. Therefore, the reason those who apportion horses make use of whips,
and those who appportion fields make use of buckles,
is not because buckles and whips surpass mankind in intelligence;
they are means by which to banish private interest and to prevent resentment from arising.
Thus, when it is said,
The Great Ruler gives responsibility to the laws and does not act personally,
the point is that the performance of tasks is judged by the laws.
65. The verdict imposed by the laws
is such that each receives his reward or his penalty in the proportion due him
and none has expectations from the ruler.
Because this is so, resentment does not arise and the relationship between sovereign and subjects is harmonious.
Listen not to words which lack the sanction of the laws;
count not as accomplishments labors which lack the sanction of the laws;
give not the responsibility of office to relatives who lack the capacity for arduous labor;
let not officials serve the private interessts of their relatives
nor the laws recognise attachments and affections.
The relationship between sovereign and subject requires not special attention -
all that matters is that both act within the sanction of the laws
